article.title: Robust Optimal Planning and Control of Non-Periodic Bipedal Locomotion with A Centroidal Momentum Model

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 shows a 3D prismatic inverted pendulum model. What does the symbol \'fr\' represent?
choices: CoM inertial force
Gravity force
Foot placement force
Ground reaction force

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 2 illustrate about 3D phase-space planning?
choices: Single contact dynamics generate valley profiles in the sagittal and lateral planes.
Step apex conditions determine the exact shape of the ground reaction forces.
Multi-contact phases are irrelevant for smooth phase-space trajectories.
Foot lateral positions are predetermined by the sagittal apex conditions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the blue region in Figure 3 represent?
choices: Invariant bundle
Recoverability bundle
Cartesian phase-space
ζ −σ space

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the symbol \'qs\' represent in the hybrid locomotion automaton depicted in Figure 4?
choices: Left leg contact
Right leg contact
Dual stance contact (stance)
Transition phase between left and right leg contact

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of step transition is depicted in Figure 5 (b)?
choices: Instantaneous step transition
Step transition with multi-contact phase
Step transition with invariant bundle
Transition bundle with a constant σ value

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of defining a local coordinate frame as shown in Figure 6 for steerable walking?
choices: To simplify the calculation of the CoM trajectory.
To visualize the robot\'s movement in a more intuitive way.
To enable lateral foot placement search orthogonal to the walking direction.
To reduce the computational burden of the planning algorithm.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the color map in Figure 7 represent?
choices: The magnitude of the CoM velocity.
The distance between the robot\'s foot and the CoM.
The terrain height.
The phase-space manifold isolines defined in Eq. (27).

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the red line in Figure 8 (b) illustrate?
choices: The nominal cotangent manifold.
The nominal tangent manifold.
A specific tangent manifold with a deviation of 2 from the nominal one.
A specific cotangent manifold with a deviation of 2 from the nominal one.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does strategy II in Figure 9 (c.2) propose to do?
choices: Adjust the CoM asymptote slope.
Adjust the next foot placement.
Increase the apex velocity of the next step.
Adjust the angular momentum at the current step.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the robust bound in Figure 10 (a) represent?
choices: The desired trajectory of the CoM.
The boundary of the invariant bundle B().
The maximum control input range.
The minimum control input range.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the left figure in Figure 11 illustrate about the recoverability bundle?
choices: The recoverability bundle is larger at the ending phase.
The recoverability bundle is larger at the beginning of the phase.
The recoverability bundle is independent of the control constraint.
The recoverability bundle is smaller when disturbances are larger.

multiple_choice_question.text: What happens in subfigures (e)-(g) of Figure 12?
choices: The DP-based continuous control is sufficient for recovery.
The disturbance is too large or occurs too close to the transition, requiring foot placement re-planning.
The robot falls down due to the large disturbance.
The robot\'s CoM successfully tracks the desired trajectory despite the disturbance.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to the end-to-end planning and control process shown in Figure 13, what happens if the disturbance checker verifies that the current trajectories are within the invariant bundle?
choices: New steps are re-planned in an online fashion.
No action is needed as the system naturally follows its CoM dynamics.
The results from the DP-based controller are utilized as a control policy.
The lateral foot placement planner is activated to adjust the robot\'s balance.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which type of terrain is the robot traversing in Figure 14 (c)?
choices: A terrain with convex steps.
A terrain with concave steps.
A terrain with inclined steps.
A flat terrain.

multiple_choice_question.text: How does the planner achieve recovery from the sagittal plane disturbance depicted in Figure 15?
choices: By using only DP continuous control.
By using both DP continuous control and discrete foot placement re-planning.
By stopping the robot\'s movement and re-planning the whole trajectory.
By adjusting the CoM surface of motion to adapt to the disturbance.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the lateral foot placement re-planning shown in Figure 16?
choices: To increase the robot\'s walking speed.
To prevent the robot from falling down due to the lateral disturbance.
To adjust the robot\'s heading direction.
To generate a smoother CoM trajectory.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 17 demonstrate?
choices: Dynamic bouncing over a disjointed terrain.
Circular walking over a random rough terrain.
Recovery from a large lateral disturbance.
The effect of different foot placements on the CoM trajectory.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 20 shows sagittal and lateral phase-space dynamics of one walking step. What does subfigure (e) depict?
choices: Lateral CoM behaviors given a fixed initial condition and varying lateral foot placements.
Lateral CoM trajectories of two consecutive steps with varying lateral foot placements.
Sagittal CoM phase behavior given a fixed foot placement.
The effect of different initial conditions on the lateral CoM behavior.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 21 illustrate about multi-contact transitions?
choices: Multi-contact transitions are not necessary for smooth CoM motion.
Multi-contact transitions can be integrated into the gait planner to achieve more natural motions.
Polynomial functions are not suitable for fitting multi-contact transition curves.
Multi-contact transitions do not affect the shape of the phase-space trajectories.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of locomotion scenario is depicted in Figure 22?
choices: Circular walking over a rough terrain.
Recovery from a large sagittal plane disturbance.
Bouncing over a disjointed terrain.
Walking over a terrain with inclined steps.
